content.webTitle: NSW ‘koala war’ flares as Gladys Berejiklian sacks parliamentary secretary for crossing floor

fields.headline: NSW ‘koala war’ flares as Gladys Berejiklian sacks parliamentary secretary for crossing floor
fields.bodyText: Gladys Berejiklian has sacked a parliamentary secretary for voting against her government’s controversial land clearing bill and said she will revert to old koala protection laws until a new policy can be drafted. The New South Wales premier made the comment on Thursday night after the Liberal MP Catherine Cusack crossed the floor to send the local land services amendment (miscellaneous) bill to a committee to debate proposed amendments, delaying its passage until next year. In a joint statement on Thursday night, Berejiklian and her deputy, the Nationals leader, John Barilaro, said the government would effectively shelve its bill, which would have exempted private rural landholders from having to recognise the expanded definition of koala habitat under the koala state environmental planning policy (Sepp) that nearly split the Coalition. They said the government would develop a new koala policy in the new year and in the meantime would revert to the old koala state environmental planning policy, known as Sepp 44. Reverting to it would take koala protections in NSW back several years and would reduce the number of feed trees identified as important for the species from 123 to 10. On Friday morning the chief executive of the Nature Conservation Council of NSW, Chris Gambian, said it was a “regression” for koala protections at a time when the animal is under assessment for a national endangered listing. “All that good work planning had done in working up a decent Sepp is wasted,” he said. “It’s outrageous. The National party has spent a lot of time this year just wasting everybody’s time.” The bill on Thursday night was sent down 18-19. It prompted a crisis meeting of the NSW National party. An hour after the meeting was scheduled to begin, Berejiklian issued a statement saying Cusack would no longer serve as a parliamentary secretary. “Following her decision today to move a non-Government amendment to a Government bill, I have made the decision to immediately remove Ms Catherine Cusack as a Parliamentary Secretary,” the premier said. Barilaro criticised those who voted to delay the legislation. “Our farmers deserve certainty and they do not deserve to be held to ransom by a Greens-controlled inquiry,” the leaders’ joint statement said. They said the NSW government would revert to Sepp 44 by the end of the month, “and in the new year we will develop a policy to protect koalas and the interests of farmers”. Sepp 44 was replaced by the koala state environmental planning policy (koala Sepp) in March, which set a new definition for koala habitat. The policy was developed after a 2016 report by the state’s chief scientist found much more needed to be done to stabilise and increase koala populations. The amendments put by the government in the bill and debated in the upper house on Thursday would have made private rural landholders exempt from that new koala habitat definition. The amendments were a compromise reached after a rift between the Liberal and National parties, with the Nationals threatening to block the reform. Berejiklian in turn threatened to strip National party ministers of their portfolios. The NSW planning minister, Rob Stokes, has previously said the new koala habitat rules would not have any impact on farmers or require them to do any extra compliance work for ordinary farming activities, such as building new sheds. It would, however, impact property developers. The Labor party and the Greens also voted to refer the legislation to the parliament’s planning and environment committee, chaired by the Greens MP Cate Faehrmann. The same committee conducted an inquiry that found that koalas are set to become extinct in NSW before 2050. Faehrmann said the legislation as drafted would have allowed land clearing to occur within “environmental zones” and removed the ability of local councils to require development applications for private native forestry operations. She said the National party had “concocted the crisis around the koala Sepp in order to progress their agenda to remove the government’s regulatory oversight of environmental protections on rural land. “The Liberals have been taken for a ride by their National party colleagues. They have every right to be angry at what’s in this bill because it does far more than simply tweak the new koala Sepp, it reads like the forestry and big agriculture industry’s wishlist come true,. “It’s abundantly clear that this bill was to be the National party’s Trojan horse which would have seen decades of work on the government’s primary mechanism to protect koalas discarded and nullify environmental protections on rural land.” She praised Cusack’s “courage” in crossing the floor. “I look forward to examining in detail the insanity of what the National party have just tried to pull off,” she said. The independent MLC, Justin Field, said the outcome of Thursday night was that the state would now have to “relitigate” koala policy next year. He said it was a “total capitulation” by Berejiklian to the National party. “It rewards Barilaro’s tantrum and it throws Catherine under a bus for raising legitimate concerns and wanting to have an inquiry,” Field said. “If you want to protect koalas, you’ve got to protect their trees. “If the Liberals keep acquiescing to National party demands, koalas will go extinct in NSW.”
